content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Thisis a very good challange

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Enjoyed solving this puzzle - original and well thought out.

P.S. Also could've been possible to do this in reverse mode, but the tiebreaker rules may be too hard to figure out in this mode

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nontrivial puzzle with interesting real world connection.

There's a lot of text. It only took a couple of minutes to read, which I don't count toward the 5 minutes, but reading quickly I missed the edge case. As a result, my code didn't pass the last test within the time limit, and I hadn't taken an approach where this could be immediately fixed. Resetting the clock, I started over with a completely new and different approach and this time passed everything in time. So I think I can approve this, but maybe it would help to trim a bit.

Goal - Decision rules
* Please change "once" to "one".

* Suggest to change "matching information" to "matches of information".

* It feels weird to guess "Russia" even when Russia is not in the list of candidate countries.

Goal - Example
* Suggest to change "best selection" to "best guess".

Thanks.

Changed, thanks!

Suppose you're correct, changed to "No guess" instead.

I agree there is a lot of text so have reduced it. The example takes a bit of space but I feel it helps clarify the task.

The "No Guess" was a bit hidden so changed the decision rule title, separated them and included it in the Output section.

It seems like there are 3 decision rules, or the two listed are tiebreaker rules, I'm not sure. Anyway this is much better, thanks. Some thoughts on possible styling:
I'd suggest putting {{language-English}} and {{telephone-+44}} in blue instead since there's a bit of competing bold text in that area. "Colon ({{:}}) separated string" or "String separated with {{:}}" would be easier to read, and [[clues]] and [[information]] in either section, or even [[country]] with the [[information]] in the input, would make it clearer what's provided. (Is the Isle of Man a country? Anyway, it may be less familiar to some.) It's also possible to treat the output as a variable, highlighting [[best guess]] as what's required.

Some changes have been made, it still needs updating I just can't get it so it isn't too crowded yet still highlights all the important information.

I believe technically Isle of Man and Jersey are crown dependencies, not countries. For simplicity though they can be called a country for this.

It's already sooo much better now, thanks! A simple fix for the crowding is to add a blank line below the headers. It makes them stand out more. Styling like bullet points (â€¢) for a list also help to define the structure without adding to the reading.

I thought of something and then reviewed this clash again and found, oops, quite a few issues in the cases:

* Validator 1:
  â€¢ Jersey: Please change "language:English" to "language-English".
  â€¢ Jersey: The input line should not end with ":".

* Validator 2:
  â€¢ Isle of Man: Please change "language:English" to "language-English".

* Validator 3:
  â€¢ The first input line should not end with ":".
  â€¢ Nigeria: There is no identifier for the last value ("yellow and white").

* Validator 4:
  â€¢ Nigeria: There is no identifier for the last value ("yellow and white").
  â€¢ Jersey: Please change "language:English" to "language-English".

* I'm able to pass all the cases by ignoring all identifiers. Is it possible to create at least two pairs of cases where identifiers matter?

Thanks.

Validator 1-4 fixed, I did go through and check all those but clearly am blind...

New tests:
Identifier Matching / Validator 5:  Checking for single ambiguous values.
Test: Checking 'front license plate-white' against any containing white (e.g. road lines)
Validator: Checking 'rear licence plate-red' against 'soil-red'

Identifier Matching 2 / Validator 6: Checking for double ambiguous values.
Test: Checking 'bollard-white' and 'road lines-white' against any containing white
Validator: Checking 'bollard-yellow and white" and 'front licence plate-white' against 'road lines-yellow and white' and any containing white

Cases
* Validator 3: Nigeria - identifier is missing for "yellow and white".

* Validator 4: Please change "language:English" to "language-English".

* Validator 5: Please change "climate:tropical" to "climate-tropical".

* Validator 6: Please change "road lines:yellow and white" to "road lines-yellow and white".

* Please standardise the identifiers' case (both "language" and "Language" are found):
  â€¢ Test 1
  â€¢ Validator 4
  â€¢ Test 6
  â€¢ Test 7

* I'm still able to pass these cases when identifiers are ignored:
  â€¢ Validator 5
  â€¢ Validator 6

For your information, my (obviously wrong) approach is to store the required values read in the first line in a set, and then for each of the candidate countries, I calculate a score equal to how many values are found in the above-mentioned set. Whenever a higher score is found, I choose that country as the guess. My approach fails in Test 5 and Test 6, but still passes in Validator 5 and Validator 6.

I often write a code to check validity of cases because I don't trust my eyes much. ðŸ˜‰

Thanks.

I did change those but think I got done over by the version mismatch error and didn't realise it didn't save.

I naively assumed that approach wouldn't be the case for all/most of them but clearly I was wrong! Altered all the test/validator cases, bar 7, so now that approach shouldn't work. Done by changing the order and including/removing information to/from some countries.

I'll double check all the inputs to ensure no other errors before submitting again, thanks!
Good job, I don't see other issues for now, and my wrong approach now fails all the cases except for the last pair ðŸ¤£
